methodology.title: How Is This Calculated?
methodology.intro: Our calculator uses a "same money in, see who ends up richer" approach to ensure a fair comparison between buying and leasing.

corePrinciple.title: Core Principle
corePrinciple.description: Both scenarios assume the same total cash outflow. When one option costs less in a given year, the savings are automatically invested. This captures the true opportunity cost of each decision.

step1.title: Track All Cash Outflows
step1.description: We calculate every dollar you spend in both scenarios:
step1.buyItems: Buy: Down payment, dealer fees, auto loan payments (principal + interest), insurance, maintenance, registration, fuel costs

step2.title: Invest the Difference
step2.description: Each year, whichever option costs less gets to invest the difference. This ensures both paths spend the same total amount, allowing for a fair comparison of final outcomes.

step3.title: Calculate Final Net Worth
step3.description: At the end of your chosen time horizon, we calculate your net worth for each scenario: vehicle value minus auto loan balance (plus any investments) for buying, and investment portfolio value for leasing. Both values account for applicable taxes.

laterYears.label: Later Years:
laterYears.description: If buying costs $8k/year but leasing costs $6k/year, the lease scenario invests that $2k difference each year. If leasing ever costs more, then buying gets to invest the difference instead.

keyTakeaway.title: Key Takeaway
keyTakeaway.description: The "Net Worth Projection" shows your final wealth under a "same money in" constraint. All spending (interest, taxes, holding costs) is fully accounted for through the investment of cost differences. You're seeing which option builds more wealth when you spend the same total amount.

cashFlow.annualExplanation: Each bar shows your yearly cash spending. When one option costs more, we treat the difference as extra investment in the other option. This ensures that the total cash spent in both options is the same.
cashFlow.cumulativeExplanation: Each bar shows your cumulative cash spending. For each year, when one option costs more, we treat the difference as extra investment in the other option. This ensures that the total cash spent in both options is the same.
